Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Directional Permeability Enhancement Using Electric Well Treatment
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is a system that provides improved reservoir productivity through a novel, inexpensive, and environmentally friendly method. This method will use an electric impulse to increase reservoir permeability, and decrease industry reliance on alternative methods like hydraulic fracturing, which requires hazardous chemicals to be pumped into the subsurface. Residents in regions where fracking techniques are utilized have commonly been impacted by induced seismicity and landslides as a consequence of pumped in chemicals lubricating faults, making earth ruptures more likely to occur. Additionally, the material and operation time for reservoir stimulation techniques makes the current process expensive. The ability to increase permeability with an electric impulse will avoid the environmental concerns associated with current methods, and will proved a cost competitive reservoir stimulation solution due to a short operational time.

This SBIR Phase I project proposes to develop a novel low-frequency impulse method (LFIM) that increases reservoir permeability for petroleum and geothermal applications, without requiring pumping of material into the subsurface. Fluid mobility is increased due to viscosity reduction and reservoir permeability is increased in the direction of interest from the vibrational removal of particles within sediment pores. This program will 1) simulate the processes taking place in the reservoir using computer simulation model, 2) perform experimental analysis of the effects of the electric treatment on different core samples, and 3) determine applicability of the method to different types of the reservoirs located in the United States. Therefore, this project will identify the optimum sites, where LFIM can boost geothermal performance and oil & gas production.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of economically viable, logistically feasible, and environmentally friendly reservoir stimulation technologies is a challenge for service companies, governments, and local communities. Current hydraulic fracturing techniques are expensive, pollutant, and consume large quantities of water. Global water supplies will become an increasingly scarce resource as the world?s climate begins to shift, and new solutions for the extraction of natural resources from the Earth?s subsurface would be required to meet the world?s energy demands. To address these issues, Eden GeoPower is developing a novel, inexpensive, and environmentally friendly reservoir stimulation technology to be used for unconventional petroleum extraction, and heat mining from geothermal resources. This method utilizes high voltage electric pulses to increase reservoir permeability and well production, while decreasing industry reliance on methods like hydraulic fracturing, which requires pumping vast amounts of water and hazardous chemicals into the subsurface. Our mission is to introduce a new technology that can reduce water usage from fracturing reservoirs by 95% and provide a total costs savings of up to 60% when compared to traditional hydraulic fracturing methods.

Throughout Phase I, we performed extensive research, experimentation, and computer modeling to demonstrate that the Pulsed Electric Reservoir Stimulation (PERS) technology we are developing is technically and economically feasible. These activities are categorized in technical research objectives of: identification of properties of rock influenced by electrothermal heating, experimental proof and analysis of electric stimulation effects on rock cores, and analysis and simulation of multiphysics processes occurring in PERS.

In general, it was found that the heating of rocks will lead to increased permeability, increased pore pressure and porosity, decreased breaking strength, and the development of fractures. Furthermore, under higher pressure and temperature of reservoirs, the electrical conductivity of rock increases, and the thermal conductivity decreases, resulting in better current flow and localized hot spots along the flow path. These results support the science of the technology, where running current through rocks causes thermal shock, microfracture initiation and development, and overall increase in well productivity. It was also found that electrical conductivity of rock formations is primarily dependent on the fluid saturation level of the rocks, and a relation for this was explored, making it possible to estimate the amount of current that will run through a specific formation when a given voltage is applied.

A laboratory testing setup was developed and utilized to acquire lab-scale data to predict the effect of PERS technology on full-scale reservoirs.  In this setup, a high-voltage pulsed power supply was used to apply a voltage difference to rock samples 1 to 6 inches in length from sandstone, carbonate, and shale formations.  Results show the method is successful in creating fractures and increasing permeability significantly in quartz- or carbonate-rich rocks such as Mancos Shale. For a specific rock type, effectiveness of the method also directly depends on conductivity and saturation of rocks, voltage difference per distance between electrodes, and discharged energy. Since the saturation level of rock decreases with energy discharge and fluid evaporation, synchronized injection of a self-dissipating and environmentally friendly conductive medium such as sodium hypochlorite is recommended for prototype design in Phase II to increase the stimulation performance in reservoirs.

A fundamental understanding of the coupled Electro-Thermo-Hydro-Mechanical-Chemical (ETHMC) multiphysics and parameters involved in PERS and their interaction under electromagnetic, thermal, and pressure fields is necessary for applicability and performance predictions of PERS based on those parameters in a reservoir. A procedure to estimate the near-wellbore skin was established that accounts for the heat dissipation by electrodes and relates it to the energy spent in thermal fracturing as well as phase change of near wellbore fluids within the fracture initiation and propagation process. The commercial reservoir simulator CMG-STARSTM was used to model the effect of pulsed heat injection on the mobility ratio during fluid-fluid displacement. As part of this, a 3D time-dependent simulation was carried out to examine the heat transfer around the wells, and it was concluded that the alternating heat and fluid injection scenario has the largest cumulative production due to the increase in mobility ratio through viscosity reduction around the producer well. An in-house MATLAB program was developed to include all governing equations related to PERS in order to resolve them based on the dimensions and parameters of an arbitrary reservoir that are input by the user. This program simulates the distributions of voltage, temperature, pressure, saturation, and other parameters between the two wells based on real characteristics of the rock formations and on well configuration over the reservoir area. Development of this program will be continued through Phase II to facilitate the estimation of required energy, PERS effectiveness, and optimum site identification.
